description:
I'm no video editing pro but for the fairly basic needs I have ShotCut works perfectly. 

There are also a lot of tutorials on the web and YouTube to explain the usage if needed
That is a good tools for edit video

I was thoroughly spoiled by screenflow on macos. Kdenlive was a horror after that, Openshot is lame, Olive and Flowblade immature, and Shotcut too hard

Now you can multi-select and move it's there. And really rock solid. I miss audio-ducking, grouping and the ability to ripple-move by dragging the scrubber ... but it works.
summary: New features make it best in class

description:
*NOTE: Version offered in Ubuntu 20.04 Software app is far outdated and crashes immediately when dragging a newly imported video to the Timeline for editing (i.e. it's useless for video editing). Be sure to get the current version (click Website in the Software app) to get it via snap with your Terminal app.
Easy to learn, lots of powerful features after you get comfortable with the basics.
i have updated to the latest version but still not able to get video on timeline track

Using it from Ubuntu 16.04 but from Ubuntu 19.10 and then 20.04 I am unable to export a MP4 with the video (only the sound)

I tried the app on their website, here, even the abomination that is the snap, NONE of them work anymore properly!!

It's sad for me to move to KDEnlive or Olive because the UI of shotcut is very friendly, but I need to move on and not be stuck for my videos
crashes the program unexpectedly when adding video clip .
I am a noob to video editing. Just wanted to cut out some pieces out of a screen recording. I was able to do so without any hassle. Great tool!

Its Free
Its Open Source
Its lightweight
Its simple
Its functional
What's not to love?
looks like I am not alone with this problem, please fix

description: I've to uninstall because isn't working in Ubuntu 20.04
Fake Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaap
The application crashes when trying to add items to the timeline.

I was having huge problems just now with adding clips. Turns out I was forgetting to drag 'n drop them into the Playlist section. Sometimes crashes when you add a video track i.e. Ctrl+I. Another thing it does is irrepairably distort frames and such---be sure to pack up your projects at least two-fold. All in all, a hell of a lot better than Flowblade or paying $80+ on software which does more than you might need.
It crash when I add a video to timeline.... what a shame...
TIME WASTE. NOT RECOMMENDED
I like the UI, it's kinda cool-but it doesn't work. If I can't add a video to the timeline, I'm just going to go for Kdelive

description: If i download the app, i get an error that makes the app not download.
pick the other one

just give some time to understand the workflow! this app helps to create wonderful video effects. if you plans to make some adjustments on your video clips this application is the "open and free" solution. You may also download latest versions using snap.
summary: Perfect for rendering effects and non-sequential editing

description: Oh my, oh my... why are you people writing "fake app" in such a shameful and sad way? This video editor, is (at my taste) not a great but a huge step on open source software for video edit. It delivers what it promises and much more. I tested it with 10 bit colors, a cast iron heavy duty task with chroma key (In short, a VFX) and it has a nice workflow, a timeline that goes as the roadrunner with OpenGL and the codecs can be managed until the last detail. So this is along with Kdenlive, and flowblade PRO VIDEO EDITING. If the flatpak (with ffmpeg isolated) is a no go for you, then get the source and compile it. But quit the useless complains and reviews based on your own frustatrion ratter than the value of the software itself. This kind of reviews should be deleted. They are not objective at all and useless.
Crashed on trying to add video track, crashed when i tried to use a solution i found in the internet, which would add video track automatically, didn't recover files correctly, then crashed...

In short, the version here doesn't work at all so I've Removed it here and will try the Snap Store link on the Shotcut website.
it has all features that I want what else is needed?

description: For a free app, it has a lot of features.
Cann't add files to timeline. it getting crashes. Please fix this error.

This gets the job done and does it quickly. I haven't had it crash as much as other people are saying, but I have had slowdowns if I run it while many other applications are open (which is to be expected)
It is one of the best video editors.
It took me maybe 10 min to get use to, and it does what it promises to do.

It's look like a pretty advance software for video editing, but I use'it just for cutting some videos. It crash if I want to use some more advanced feature like multiple video use the timeline or multiple timeline...
really bad, i cannot even drag video to timeline, it turns off...
Things are in very difficult places

summary: Can confirm, this apps sole purpose is to crash

description: I used this in the past and it was great. Easy to learn with zero background in editing. Now it just crashes.
summary: Unusable, crashes immediately when you add a video to the timeline

description: Fast and easy to use, with many options for simple video editing.
One of the best free video editor definitely deserves five stars.

Keeps crashing, constantly low on memory, LAGS when you ZOOM IN (HOW?), overall horrible experience. My system runs vegas pro 13, davinci resolve and kdenlive PERFECTLY , no lagging no crashing no memory issues - but this? Horrible.
I tried using this instead of Kdenlive (because it lags playing a video) and it is impressive! I am using this on a Raspberry Pi 400 and it runs like my professional version of Videopad on Windows.
Would have loved to try it
Great app, works smoothly on my low end laptop linux machine (ubuntu budgie)

I did a slideshow with this and it was very easy. I also like the background blur option. However, for more serious editing, I found it laggy on both Windows and Linux. Not using the best hardware but Kdenlive outperformed it on Linux.

I didn't find the UI very clean to work with. Most video editors I've used have been pretty easy to figure out, but I just couldn't really figure out how to use this one for the life of me. Also, it crashed a couple of times for some of the smallest things which was super annoying. Had to uninstall unfortunately.

I am amazed at the non 5-star reviews. This app is incredible and has all the functions of a Adobe Premiere and works well on low end machines. The editing is intuitive, but if you need to do something like a blur mask on a face, you have to learn how to use filters, which you can do in about one minute w a Youtube search. Awesome, fully functional video editing software which allowed me to abandon Windows. Linux has finally arrived and is now user friendly in addition to being the superior OS.
summary: All the functions of a Adobe Premiere and more

description: for beginners with no idea how to edit a video, I have absolutely no problem deleting part of an audio file with Audacity or doing anything else, so it's not a question of aptitude but appears to be one of presentation...
come to my place ;)
It is too complicated for my purposes and there is no package to remove it.

Ever since switching from Windows 11 I've been looking for a Davinci Resolve alternative. I couldn't get it working on Fedora 36. Kdenlive was too complex with clunky UI and poor performance.

Simple things like colour correction and crossfades were needlessly confusing. While it may be more powerful it just wasn't for me. Flowblade had better UI, but was still slow and lacking in updates.

Shotcut is the best Linux video editor I've used so far. Noticably faster, decent colour grading, detects my hardware instantly, and crossfades are simple. The UI isn't half bad either.
A lot more advanced, offering some incredible features, and a lot more responsive structure, the capabilities of using a GPU is also an awesome feature to have
summary: A Great Step Up From OpenShot

description: Constantly crashes
Has always treated me well for simple video editing.

I've used a lot of video editing software on Windows/Mac before but I've always been disappointed with what's been available for Linux, until now. It took me longer to install Shotcut then it did to edit 10 minutes of drone footage down into 2 minutes, complete with transitions between cuts and a nice audio track. All this and no crashes or weird error messages!
summary: Excellent app if you have previous video editing experience

description: How come the update for shotcut doesn't show up on this app called software? When I tried to update shotcut on PureOS by downloading online, it's not working.
summary: Shotcut was installed on PureOS but it wants me to update it

description: I have noticed when I use zoom on accessibility zoom settings it will lock the system up tight. So for lockups try toggling settings that don't seem to make sense. If I turn it off it works fine. ubuntu version Ubuntu 22.10, gnome 43.1, Wayland
summary: Crashes when using accessibility zoom setting [perhaps more]

description:
I just want import, edit, export - not every damned function under the sun.
It needs a "Simple Mode".
It has to be the best open source video editing application I've ever used.

This snap version of Shotcut appears to be completely broken, at least for me. A recent MP4 export with NVENC that I uploaded to youtube played normally for about 35 seconds, and then video locked up while audio continued to play. I had noticed that VLC had similar behavior as well, but initially assumed it was an issue with VLC since Shotcut and other players (except SMPlayer) played the output file just fine.

I have since re-exported using the matching flatpak version of shotcut, now both VLC and SMPlayer are handling it just fine.
The Flatpak is also much more performant in the UI than the snap version, so please do yourself a favor and grab the flatpak if you must.

Now if only the APT sources version was not from January 2022.
LIke any other reviewer said, it keeps crashing when dragging a file from the playlist to the timeline. This wasn't a problem in 22.04. I regret updating Ubuntu to 23.04 now.

Last updated

  29 July 2023
I have bees searching for something imilar to Filmora on lunix and this is the closest i could't get, the pre defined effects and filters are really good too. and its open source.
Crashes when you add videos into the timeline
Just like Openshot will not open on Ubuntu 22.04 what is it with this new update? Worked great for a month now nothing works.

I use this routinely for youtube video production. It is relatively easy to learn and use, and has all the functionality of any non-free software video editor.

Works great in Fedora from 33-38. Seeing a lot of 1 star reviews for Ubuntu users, so I cannot speak for other distros.
summary: Best general purpose FOSS video editor

description: A basic multipurpose video editor that does what Davinci Resolve Linux cannot currently do ... edit mp4 AAC media.
Not properly installing audio EQ filters in Xubuntu. Missing EQ filters, and many others. Shotcut is not finding the Ladspa library
summary: Missing Audio EQ Filters in Xubuntu

description: at least it opens and loads a file..... more later

For me this one installs fine and works much better than kdenlive. It freezes for a bit when importing videos or doing CTRL-X CTRL-V on many timeline items, but it doesn't crash and the user experience is decent overall. Great job!

i spend 3 days trying to export a video, a simple video track with audio track but nooooo every damn fuking time it has to crash and no matter what i do its still crashing and crashing and crashing. how can this app has this many stars ? i dont even know but its def good for nothing

After installing, launching, and failing to modify, or preview, my projects on 4 other NLEs, I can say with a measure of confidence, that at least this one works. It imports sorce video/audio as I tell it to. It lets me do basic video editing right from the start.

The frustrating thing is the tools don't make clear how to use them for beginners, and the Help menu items are of NO HELP WHATSOEVER. There is no easy, nor intuitive, way to overlay one image/video over the video you want to make the primary video. No clear cut method of altering color/lighting schemes. No readily appearant means of adding subtitles.

Obviously, this has a HUGE learning curve. But, again, it works. Here's hoping I can make it work for my purposes.
summary: Works out of the Box....Just need to learn the tools

description: It is a good video editor, however lacks subtitle support. You can only add text overlays, which doesn't do the same job as I cannot export .srt files that way. I hope they add proper subtitle feature in the future.
could've been simpler

Works best on Windows systems with full graphics card support; ie encode and decode functionality. Otherwise you might see a splatt (Kubuntu 23.10 lacks AMD HD7750 GPU enc & dec drivers) message from time to time. Seems to be okay with NVidia Pascal drivers for the Quadro P400 GPU.

Very easy to have videos up and running. It did take a learning curver but worth it. Now If we can "Ai this up," with automatic generated placeholder text and nice fonts etc that would be a yuge time saver. Almost there definitely a must for Ubuntu users. Thank you
summary: Outstanding Work perfect for Youtube Videos and Shorts

description:
Not the most intuitive or attractive interface, but some things (such as transitions between clips) can be done very easily compared to other NLEs. There's a good bit of glitchiness on Wayland in particular, but it's generally cosmetic.

The big advantage this has compared to other free (and not necessarily OSS) NLEs is support for 10-bit rendering. I much prefer Kdenlive's interface and extensibility, so when 10-bit rendering is supported with effects by Kdenlive, I'll be going back to that.
Leider startet dieses Programm ganz und gar nicht, wenn ich versuche es zu starten. Jedoch kann es an der Architektur meines CPUs liegen (ARM64) ich habe ein Manjaro ARM mit einem Raspberry Pi 400
stürzt bei allem ab. bedienkonzept nicht einleuchtend.

Benutze Shotcut jetzt schon viele Jahre und bin über dessen Stabilität immer wieder positiv erstaunt. Die Bedienung für die grundlegenden Dinge ist sehr einfach. Wenige Dinge erfordern ein wenig Einarbeitung. Ich kann deutlich kompliziertere Schnittsysteme.
Zum Schneiden, Rendern und Zusammenfügen einfach unentbehrlich.
Stürzt leider andauernd ab, vor allem wenn man ein Element in die Timeline zieht.

imho bester Videoeditor unter Linux.

Bitte aktuell halten - das snap ist ein Jahr alt

Habe sehr lange Openshot benutzt, aber das wurde mit Version zu Version verbugter. Bei Shotcut ist es genau anders herum, das war früher unter 20.04 verbugt, ist mittlerweile gut.
Wenn man sich an die Bedienung gewohnt hat, flutscht alles einwandfrei.

Habe die 3 bekanntesten Videoschnitt Progs für Linux getestet u. bin wieder zu ShotCut zurück. Läuft u.a. stabil unter LMDE, Sparky, Manjaro und Garuda. Einsatz auf einem PC und 2 NBs Acer u. Asus, alle mit i7 Prozessor 8 jahre alt. Wer mit der Schnitt Materie nicht so vertraut ist, erhält im Netz viele, teils sehr gute Lernvideos.

lief erst stabil nachdem ich die Appversion von deren Originalwebseite nutzte. Mir fehlen immer noch einige Dinge (z.B. beim insertieren sollen auch zusätzliche Spuren synchron bleiben)
Gut wäre auch, dass ich mal schnell eine Variante ablegen kann (Subsequenzen erstellen) ohne ein neues Projekt zu eröffnen
summary: erstaunlich stabil mit der aktuellen Version von deren Webseite

description: Verwende Shotcut seit einigen Jahren für meinen Youtube-Kanal. Es funktioniert einwandfrei. Viele Einstellungsmöglichkeiten, einfach zu verstehendes Interface, Hardwarebeschleunigung für AMD und Nvidia ist dabei (automatisch erkannt via Knopfdruck), regelmäßige Updates, viele Effekte und kostenlos. Sehr zu empfehlen!

Bei mir Startet es nicht unter Kubuntu.
Snap version geht, aber da fehlen die Effecte.

Hatte bis vor kurzem einen Mac und habe iMovie verwendet.
1. Shotcut stürzt häufig ab
2. Dateien sind in der Zeitleiste werden aber nicht mehr gefunden. Wenn man das Projekt schließt oder Exportieren fehlen Dateien. 
3. Bedienung ist absurt kompliziert. 
Man verbrennt unglaublich viel Zeit mit Neustart und Daieien suchen und reparieren was nur schlecht funktioniert.
Shotcut ist unbrauchbar
Desde que conocí este software ya no lo cambié. De lo mejor que he probado. Es muy completo y con mucha información en youtube. Recomendable!
summary: Todo lo necesario, potente y ligero

nunca exporta, no sirve

Muy buen editor de video y en constante desarrollo. Casi todos los meses hay una nueva actualización con arreglo de errores y nuevas características.
Muchos se quejan de tener problemas, pero es porque usan la versión añeja que trae sus distros.
Uso la versión Flathub (Flatpak), funciona bien y siempre está actualizada!

Народ, у кого падает, ставьте appimage с сайта разработчика. У меня такой вариант работает достаточно стабильно. Пользуюсь постоянно. Нравится гораздо больше чем KDEnLive. Про Ctrl+S, конечно, забывать нельзя :-)
